Marine record: biomarkers and geochemistry 

BIT index 

Lipid extraction of freeze-dried powdered samples was performed with ultrasonic probes. Extracts were saponified 
and further separated on Bond-Elut SiO2 columns; polar fractions containing glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers 
(GDGTs) were eluted with 2 mL MeOH. Prior to analysis by high performance liquid chromatography / atmospheric 
pressure chemical ionization – mass spectrometry (HPLC/APCI-MS), samples were filtered through a 4 µm pore size 
PTFE filter and dissolved in hexane/isopropanol (99:1; v/v). An Agilent 1200 series HPLC/APCI-MS system equipped 
with a Grace Prevail Cyano column (150 mm x 2.1 mm; 3 µm) was used, and separation was achieved in normal 
phase using the method described by Leider et al. [2010]. GDGTs were detected by selective ion monitoring of the 
protonated molecular ion (M+H) peaks. Peaks with the following protonated molecular ion masses were considered: 
1022 (I), 1036 (II), 1050 (III), and 1292 (crenarchaeol). The BIT index was calculated according to Hopmans et al. 
[2004] as 
  
BIT = [I+II+III] / [I+III+III+crenarchaeol]                                       (1) 
 

Ti/Ca 

Concentrations of Ti and Ca in GeoB3910-2 were determined based on ICP-OES measurements after microwave acid 
total digestion of freeze dried and homogenized sediments. Complete digestion of about 50 mg of sediment was 
achieved using a MLS ETHOS 1600 Microwave system the following quantities of acids: 3 ml HNO3, 2 ml HCl, and 0.5 
ml HF. After evaporation of the acids, the residues were re-dissolved in 1 M HNO3. The accuracy of the analytical 
procedure was checked by processing the standard reference sediment NIST SRM 2702 every 4-5 samples. Element 
concentrations (Ca and Ti) were subsequently determined by ICP-OES using a Thermo Scientific IRIS Intrepid 
instrument. A multi-element standards solution at 5 different concentrations prepared from single element stock 
solutions in 1 M HNO3 was used for calibration of the measurement. 

Text S3. 

Results  

Speleothem ?
18

O profiles 

The oxygen isotopic composition of speleothem carbonate is strongly tied to the isotopic composition of the rainfall 
that seeps through the top of the karst aquifer [Fairchild et al., 2006]. In tropical areas deep convection and vertical 
uplift of air masses produces an isotopic effect known as “amount effect” [Vuille et al., 2003]. In essence, the amount 

effect is the inverse proportional variation of the ?
18

O of the rainfall with the amount of precipitation [Lachniet, 
2009]. At the Lapa Sem Fim cave site, an isotopic monitoring program of rainfall performed since 2011 shows that 
the isotopic composition of rainfall is strongly controlled by the amount-effect (Figure S1). The observed correlation 
(R

2
=0.73) at monthly time scales for the cave site is confirmed by the strong negative correlation between monthly 

rainfall amount and monthly mean ?
18

O at the IAEA-GNIP station in Brasília between 1963 and 1987 (R
2
=0.65), where 

precipitation is climatologically identical to the study region (Figure S1). 

Relatively low correlation coefficients between ?
18

O and ?
13

C along the speleothem’s growth axes (Hendy test) 
suggest that stalagmites LSF16 (R

2
=0.24) and PX7 (R

2
=0.33) were deposited close to isotopic equilibrium. However 

the Hendy test is not decisive to determinate isotopic equilibrium conditions [Mickler et al., 2004]. In further 
validation of the Hendy test, the good correspondence between the Lapa Sem Fim (LSF16) and Paixão (PX7) isotope 

records reinforces the notion that the ?
18

O fluctuations represent information of paleoclimatic significance on a 
regional scale. 



 

 
 

233 
ANEXO 

The ?
18

O isotope values of the Paixão cave records present clear differences in terms of their absolute values (Figure 
S3). In general, the stalagmites from Lapa Sem Fim cave feature values that are 2 to 3 ‰ more depleted when 
compared with northeastern stalagmites. The depletion is in agreement with an expected isotope effect caused by 
the Rayleigh distillation. The Rayleigh distillation describes the lowering of the isotope values as a consequence of 
the progressive condensation and removal of heavier isotopes during condensation in an air mass [Fairchild et al., 
2006, Lachniet, 2009].  

The amplitudes of the ?
18

O depletion within the different wet events during HS1 are equivalent between the Lapa 
Sem Fim and Paixão stalagmite records despite the discrepancy in absolute values (Figure S2 and S3). For instance, 
during the dry phase centered at 16.5 kyr B.P., both isotope records undergo an isotopic enrichment of ca. 2.3 ‰. 
The same holds true during the most humid event (i.e., HS1a) at 16.0 kyr B.P., when both records present an isotopic 
depletion of about 2.5 ‰ (Figure S2 and S3).

Abstract 

Paleoclimate studies based on speleothem records suggest that variation in insolation 

precession and ocean circulation plays an important role in controlling the moisture transport 

along the South Atlantic Convergence Zone (SACZ), causing abrupt rainfall redistribution over 

central Brazil. However, little is known about paleoclimate changes in regions directly affected 

by the SACZ close to its modern axis. In this study we present a novel paleoprecipitation 

reconstruction based on precisely dated ?
18

O speleothem records from central-eastern 

covering the last 85 kyr. At orbital time-scale monsoon precipitation over central-eastern Brazil 

shows limited coupling with insolation forcing, except for the interval between 60 and 85 kyr 

BP. This feature is attributed to an additional forcing by the glacial boundary conditions that 

significantly influence the position and strength of the SACZ. On the other hand, during the last 

glacial, the precipitation variability over the eastern portion of the SACZ region was strongly 

modulated by millennial-scale climate oscillation recorded on high latitude areas of North 

Hemisphere. Particularly during the marine isotope stage 3, changes in monsoon precipitation 

near the axis of SACZ mimics abrupt oscillation pacing by the transition of Greenland stadial 

and interstadial events. During the wet stadial phases addition increments in the strength of 

South American monsoon precipitation over central-eastern Brazil show consistent patterns in 

terms of the timing and structure with the episodes of massive deposition of ice rafting debris 

in the North Atlantic. Our results suggest a farther southward displacement of the Intertropical 



 

 
 

243 ANEXO 

Convergence Zone occurred as a consequence to Northern Hemisphere mid-latitude cooling 

caused by the massive surging of icebergs. In this context, it is possible that the amplitude of 

millennial scale paleoprecipitation variability over the SACZ region may played an important 

hole on species dispersion through the forest corridors between the Amazon and Atlantic rain 

forests. 

Introduction 

 

Central-eastern Brazil includes one of the most important ecotonal zones of South 

America, located in the boundaries of important biomes comprehended by the 

phytogeographic domains of Atlantic forest (Moist Broadleaf Forest), Cerrado (mostly savanna-

like) and Caatinga (Xeric Schrublands) (Figure 1) (Myers et al., 2000; Klink and Machado, 2004; 

Santos et al., 2011; Giongo et al., 2011; Ratter et al., 1997). Vigorous episode of strengthening 

in the South America Monsoon System (SAMS) during the last glacial (Wang et al., 2004; Cheng 

et al., 2013a) is thought to have worked as bridge for species dispersion connecting the Moist 

Broadleaf Forest biomes of the Atlantic and Amazon Forest (Costa, 2003).  

The rainfall over Central-eastern Brazil is entirely modulated by the strength and 

position of the South Atlantic Convergence Zone (SACZ). The SACZ is a key feature of the South 

America Monsoon System (SAMS) characterized as an elongated convective band extending 

from western Amazon basin to southeastern Brazil and protruding into southeastern 

subtropical South Atlantic (Carvalho et al., 2004; Vera et al., 2006, Marengo et al., 2012). 

Variation in the strength and position of the SACZ accounts for most of the climate variability 

over SAMS domain (Carvalho et al., 2004). Given that SACZ plays a fundamental role in the 

precipitation variability over tropical South America determining the patterns of variation of 

the hydrologic regime over the SACZ region is of paramount importance to decipher what are 

the potential driving forces capable to affect the development of biomes over tropical and 

subtropical areas. However, currently paleoclimate records covering this region are sparse and 

temporal fragmented. In fact, as a whole, far too little is known about the behavior of SAMS 

over Central Brazil at orbital and on millennial-scale as well. In the context of the lack of 

continuous and long paleoclimate record over the SACZ region here we present a novel 

paleomonsoon reconstruction covering the last 85 kyr based on absolute well dated 

speleothem ?
18

O record. Our results bring new assessments about the spatial pattern of 

changes in the hydrologic regime of SAMS at millennial and orbital time-scale with important 

implications for the reconstruction of biogeography patterns in South America. 



 

 
 

244 ANEXO

Site description 

 

The speleothems used in this study were collected in two distinct caves located in 

central-eastern: Lapa Sem Fim (16°08’52’’S, 44°36’38’’W) and Lapa Grande (14°22’45.91”S, 

44°17’19.72”W), respectively. The distance between the two caves is about 290 km (Figure 1).  

The present-day climate at Lapa Sem Fim and Lapa Grande cave sites is tropical 

savannah-like with dry winters (Aw) and arid, steppe-like hot (BSh) respectively, according to 

the Köppen-Geiger classification (Peel et al., 2007). The annual mean precipitation of the 

studied areas is around 950 mm (source: www2.ana.gov.br). The precipitation occurs almost 

exclusively during the active period of the SAMS, starting in October and ending in April, with a 

maximum activity between November and February that corresponds to almost 70% of total 

annual precipitation (see supporting Text S1 and Figures S1). The study area is currently 

occupied by the Cerrado phytogeographic domain also considered as biomes itself. The 

Cerrado domain covers a vast area of central-Brazil (23% of land surface of the country) and is 

dominated by semi-deciduous arboreal savanna characteristic of the Tropical/Subtropical 

Grassland, Savanna and Schrublands biome with enclaves of mesophytic deciduous and semi-



 

 
 

245 ANEXO 

deciduous forest belonging to the Tropical/Subtropical Dry Broadleaf Forest biome (Olson et 

al., 2001; Coutinho et al., 2005; Klink and Machado, 2004; Ratter et al., 1997).

Delta Plus Advantage at the University of São Paulo. Reproducibility of standard materials is 

0.1 ‰ for ?

O. The ages were obtained by using a multi-collector inductively coupled plasma 

mass spectrometry technique (MC-ICP-MS, Thermo-Finnigan NEPTUNE) at the University of 

Minnesota following the procedures described by Cheng (2013b). Most dates present errors 

(2?)<1% (supplementary Table S1). The samples weighing between 150 and 300 mg were

Results 

Our record is based on a suite of 11 stalagmites belonging to Lapa Grande and Lapa 

Sem Fim caves. The speleothem stable oxygen isotope (?
18

O) records from central-eastern 

Brazil presented here are based on 4828 samples, yielding a mean temporal resolution of near 

20 years. The chronological control of our speleothem record is based on 112 U/Th dates: 34 

for stalagmite from Lapa Grande and 78 for stalagmite from Lapa Sem Fim cave. The central-

eastern Brazil speleothem record cover most portion of the last 85 kyr, presenting local hiatus, 

mainly distributed along the MIS3 (Figure 2). In general, the ?
18

O values from Lapa Grande 

speleothem record are around 1.5 ‰ more enriched than those from Lapa Sem Fim. Besides 

the difference recorded in absolute values, as we can observe in Figures 2 both isotope record 

describes consistent variations at millennial and orbital times-scale. At millennial time-scale 

the isotope record is characterize by numerous oscillation of high amplitude, near 3 ‰, with 

some excursion showing clear abrupt transitions recording changes up to 3.5 ‰ of magnitude 

in less than 85 years. Those abrupt events are coherent to the time of Heinrich layer 

depositions (Figures 3 and 4). At orbital time-scale, changes in ?
18

O records variation up to 4.6 

‰, as observed between 71.5 to 62.2 kyr BP (Figure 2).  



 

 
 

246 ANEXO 

An isotope monitoring program on rainfall performed from 2011-2015 in the study 

area  points to amount effect as primary factor influencing the ?
18

O of precipitation over 

central-eastern Brazil (Figure 2). The monitoring station is precisely positioned between the 

caves sites located at the meteorological station from the National Brazilian Meteorological 

Institute (Instituto Nacional de Meteorologia - INMET) (15°26'52.99"S; 44°21'58.66"W), 

Januária city.  The weighted mean monthly ?
18

O recorded from the precipitations presents a 

strong negative correlation with the mean monthly rainfall at 99.9 % (r = -0.92, p-value<0.001) 

(Figure S2). The correlation between monthly rainfall amount and monthly mean ?
18

O assessed 

for the study site is consistent with data from IAEA-GNIP station in Brasília between 1963 to 

1987 (r =- 0.82, p- value<0.001), where precipitation is climatologically identical to the study 

region. 

Discussion 

Climate assessments 

 

At the eastern portion of SAMS domain the role solar insolation over monsoonal 

precipitation variability is complex. As we can observe in the Figure 2 during the last eighty five 

thousand years monsoon precipitation over central-eastern Brazil presents locally coupling 

with the solar insolation curve, restricted to the interval between 60 and 85 kyr BP. The 

behavior is similar to the observed in the ?
18

O speleothem record from western Amazon basin 

(Cheng et al., 2009) (Figure 2) and points to non-linear mechanism, probably dependent of 

oceanic boundary conditions, connecting the strength and position of SACZ to solar insolation 

forcing. More specifically, central-eastern Brazil lies in the edge of zonal circulation system, 

defined as Bolivian High-Nordeste Low system (Lenters and Cook, 1997). The Bolivian High-

Nordeste Low system is an east-west upper tropospheric circulation that rises in response to 

moisture convergence over the Amazon basin and the resultant large-scale subsidence over 

Northeastern Brazil (Lenters and Cook, 1997; Gandu and Dias, 1998; Chen and Weng, 1999). 

On orbital time-scale the Bolivian High-Nordeste Low system is known to promote an eastern-

western South Atlantic precipitation dipole (SAPD) leading to anti-phased orbital modulation 

of monsoon precipitation between western Amazon and Southern Brazil with northeastern 

Brazil (Cruz et al., 2009; Cheng et al., 2013a) (Figure 1). The role of the Bolivian High-Nordeste 

Low system on driven precipitation variability at orbital-time scale over the studied area is also 

evidenced by the zonally oriented antiphased behavior recorded between central-eastern and 



 

 
 

247 ANEXO 

western Amazon paleomonsoon reconstruction (Figure 2). Following this reasoning, the more 

restrictive coupling observed between solar forcing and monsoon precipitation over central-

eastern Brazil might arise in reason of the vicinity of our study site from the SACZ axis placing 

this site as a transitory region of the SAPD influence. Thus, depending on the boundary 

conditions, the SACZ may act as a climate buffer barring the influence of insolation forcing over 

monsoon intensity. 

Nevertheless, the most noticeable feature of precipitation variability over central-

eastern Brazil occurs at millennial-scale oscillation. As demonstrated in the Figure 2, during the 

last glacial the precipitation variability over the eastern portion of the SACZ region was 

strongly modulated by millennial-scale climate oscillation recorded on high latitude areas of 

North Hemisphere.  Particularly during the Marine Isotope Stage (MIS) 3 (~27-60 kyr BP), 

variations in the intensity of SACZ mimics abrupt oscillation pacing by the transitions of stadial 

(cold) and interstadial (warm) events recorded in the ?
18

O isotope stratigraphy of Greenland 

ice cores (North Greenland Ice Core Project members, 2004; Sanchez-Goñi and Harrison, 2010; 

Rasmussen et al., 2014a) (Figures 2 and 3).  The millennial-scale variability observed in the 

speleothem record from Central-eastern Brazil presents a different scenario from that 

recorded in the Ti/Ca of marine sediments from off northeastern Brazil (Jaeschke et al., 2007). 

While the Ti/Ca record points to climate fluctuation exclusively tied to the Heinrich Stadial (HS) 

events the speleothem record shows a remarkable coupling of the SAMS intensity to stadial 

and interstadial events (see supporting Figures S3, S4 and Figure 3).

18

O record in the GICC05modelext time scale (North 

Greenland Ice Core Project members, 2004); (b) MIS curve based on ?
18

O of benthic foraminiferals 

(Lisiecki & Raymo, 2005); (c) ?
18

O speleothem record from central-eastern Brazil (this study); (e) 
speleothem record from El Condor cave (black) and Cueva del Diamante (green) eastern flank of the 
Andes (Cheng et al., 2013a); (g) speleothem record from Botuverá cave, Southern Brazil (Cruz et al., 
2005); (d), (f) and (g) December, January February insolation curve calculated for 10°S (Berger and

The high amplitude of millennial-scale ?
18

O
 
variability (> 3‰) points to substantial 

changes in monsoon precipitation at the time of stadial-interstadial events and at the time of 

Heinrich Stadial (HS) events as well (Figures 3 and S4). The impact of stadial events on the 

hydrologic regime of Central-eastern Brazil is also evidenced in paleo water-table fluctuation 

recorded in calcite rimes at the Lapa Grande cave walls (Figures 3 and supporting Figure S5). At 

Lapa Grande cave U-Th age of a underwater carbonate coating located in edge of the cave 

walls (35.87 ± 1.2 kyr BP) developed on current dry conduit points to significant increase in 

ground water recharge at the epoch of  Greenland Stadial 8 (36.58 – 35.48 kyr BP). Analog 

oscillation in the ground-water recharge recorded over northeastern Brazil based on water-

table speleothems reinforces the imprint of cold millennial stadial events in the hydrologic 



 

 
 

249 ANEXO 

regime in the Central-eastern/Northeastern Brazil sector (Auler and Smart, 2001).  Indeed, 

over Central-eastern and Northeastern Brazil we frequent faced certain level of speleothem 

deposition, illustrated by giant stalagmites and fossil travertines, whose occurrence witness a 

more vigorous hydrological regime than today.  

The good coupling between monsoon precipitation over Central-eastern and 

Northeastern Brazil with North Hemisphere high latitude temperature is explained by the 

latitudinal shifts in the mean position of the ITCZ as consequence of changes in the tropical 

interhemispheric SST gradient (Chiang and Bitz, 2005; Cvijanivic and Chiang, 2013). The 

progression of surface cooling at mid and low-latitudes during stadial and HS events are the 

main causes of southward displacements of the ITCZ, whose position is dynamically 

determined by the tropical interhemispheric SST gradient (Chiang and Bitz, 2005). In the same 

way the strength and position of the SACZ is sensitive to the convective activity in the Amazon 

basin (Vera et al., 2006; Carvalho et al., 2004; Marengo et al., 2012). This concept is reinforced 

by the strike resemblance between Central-eastern Brazil paleo-monsoon reconstruction and 

combined annual-resolved terrigenous input record from Cariaco basin (Deplazes et al., 2013) 

and mid-latitude SST reconstruction from north Atlantic (Figure 4).

250 ANEXO 

During the wet stadial phases located increments in the strength of SAMS over Central-

eastern Brazil are coherent with the episodes of massive depositional of ice rafting debris 

(IRD). As we can observe in the Figure 3 and 4 a sharp increase in monsoon precipitation 

characterized by a steep and brief decrease of ?
18

O, lasting less than 85 years, are frequent 

recorded close to the period of Heinrich layers deposition. During the ice berg surging related 

to the HS1, H2, H4 and H5 the isotope record from Central-eastern in combination with 

Northeastern Brazil register negative excursion higher than 3 ‰, reaching values varying from 

-7 to -9 ‰ (Figure 4). However the same does not holds to Cariaco record. As we can observed 

in Figure 4, at the time of ice rafted deposition no further perturbation in monsoon 

precipitation over Cariaco drainage basin can be distinguished. This assessment reinforces the 

hypothesis that during stadial events, the mean position of the ITCZ was permanently 

displaced southern of 10 °N in the Atlantic sector (Zarriess et al., 2011; Deplazes et al., 2013).  

The uncertainties in ice core chronology derived from stratigraphic disturbances can 

rich values as high 1700 years for the period of the MIS3 (Rasmussen et al., 2014b). In addition, 

uncertainties in marine core chronology among, other factors, from the low temporal 

resolution and large dating uncertainties of the commonly used 14C-dated records (Austin and 

Hibbert, 2012) prevents to establishing a precise chronology for the timing of environmental 

and climate changes between continental and marine paleoclimate archives. Thus, in face of 

the strike resemblance between monsoon variability at SACZ region and North Hemisphere 

high- and mid-latitude surface temperature speleothem isotope record from tropical areas 

offers an alternative to ice-core chronology calibration and dating of Heinrich layers (Figures 3 

and 4). In fact, atmospheric global circulation model coupled to slab ocean suggests that the 

high latitude temperatures propagates into the tropics within a matter of years (Chiang and 

Bitz, 2005; Cvijanovic and Chiang, 2013).

2+

In order to better understand the main triggers of climate changes on monsoonal 

precipitation over Central-eastern Brazil in Figure 4 we visually tied peaks of increase in 



 

 
 

252 ANEXO 

monsoon precipitation during stadial events recorded on Central-eastern Brazil with minor 

changes terrestrial matter input recorded from Cariaco basin, synchronized with GICC05 ice 

core chronology and peaks of ice rafted deposition at Iberian Margin. As we can observe in 

Figure 4 in contrast to northern Atlantic mid-latitude SST and the South American monsoonal  

precipitation record, over Greenland almost no significant climate perturbation is noticed 

during the episodes of massive ice-rafted deposition (North Greenland Ice Core Project 

members, 2004). Except for the HS2, the temperature and the strength of polar vortex remains 

nearly constant whereas SST at Iberian margin and SAMS over central-eastern Brazil 

underwent abrupt oscillation at millennial-scale during the events of ice berg surging. The 

concordant behavior observed on both, ?
18

O and Ca
2+

 record (Rasmussen et al., 2014a) 

suggests a climate buffering of high latitude areas to Heinrich events, possible in reason of sea-

ice progression. Indeed in the course of MIS2, during the stadials 2 and 3 (27.73 – 14.64 kyr 

BP), the atmosphere temperature over Greenland describes a quite monotonous series of 

climate oscillation when compared with SST temperatures over mid-latitude areas of North 

Atlantic.  

Ecological insights 

 

At the time of Younger Dryas (12.89-11.7 kyr B.P.) and HS1 events (18-14.69 kyr B.P.) 

(Wang et al., 2004) travertine paleobotanical remains from Salitre river valley (10°30’ S; 40° W) 

on northeastern Brazil, (~ 500 km northern from the studied site) points to the occurrence of 

dense mesophytic semi-deciduous forest on current dry Caatinga forest. In the same direction, 

our speleothem records points to substantial increase in monsoon at millennial time-scale 

extending throughout the stadial events of the last glaciation. 

The turbulent history of past rainfall variability over the SACZ region presented here 

(Figures 2 and 3) supports the notion that the boundaries of biomes enclosed in the Amazon, 

Cerrado, Caatinga and Atlantic forest phytogeographic domains underwent though abrupt 

shifts. As demonstrated in the Figure 1 the Cerrado  (savanna-like vegetation) and Caatinga 

(tropical dry forest) domains acts as barriers separating the two major rain forest biomes of 

Brazil depicted by the Amazon and Atlantic Forest (Costa, 2003). The strengthening in 

monsoon precipitation across the SACZ during cold millennial events may have played an 

important role on species dispersion through the establishment of forest corridors between 

the Amazon and Atlantic rain forests. This concept is supported by the broad overlap of taxa of 

mammals and amphibians from both Amazon and Atlantic forest on patches of mesophytic 

forest across the biomes of Cerrado (Redford and Fonseca, 1986; Costa, 2003; Oliveira-Filho 



 

 
 

253 ANEXO 

and Ratter, 1995; Johnson et al., 1999) and in the transition zone depicted by the Tropical Dry 

Broadleaf Forest (Valdujo et al., 2009). Considering their narrow habitat tolerance it is 

noteworthy to account for the importance of the amphibian to the biogeography studies 

whereas habitat connectivity plays an important role in regional viability of amphibian 

population (Cushman, 2006). 

  Conclusions 

 

Our results also have important implications for the reconstruction of biogeography 

and speciation patterns in South America due to species dispersion through the forest 

corridors between the Amazon and Atlantic rain forests during glacial millennial-cold events 

(Wang et al., 2004), although such events of climatic changes may have displayed similar 

patterns in the past far beyond our records. Substantial increases in SAMS across de SACZ 

domain at the time of stadial and HS events may have conditioned the expansion of a dense 

mesophytic semi-deciduous forest over a large region across Central and Northeastern Brazil, 

which today is dominated by Savanna (Cerrado) and dry forest (Caatinga), connecting habitat 

from the Amazon to the Atlantic rain forest.

Text S1 - Precipitation at the study site 

The mean annual precipitation at the study site was estimated based on data from 8 

local meteorological stations from 1936 – 2014. The rainfall dataset was obtained from the 

National Brazilian Meteorological Institute (Instituto Nacional de Meteorologia - INMET) 

website (www.inmet.gov.br) and from the Agência Nacional de Água (ANA) website 

(www.ana.gov.br). As each of these records are discontinuous, we applied a regional vector 

following the Brunet-Moret method using the software HYDRACCESS
1
. This method, developed 

by the French Institute of Research for the Development (IRD), consists in the construction of a 

fictive station which takes into account the gap of the records and calculates an annual index 

exerting a mean value equal to 1 throughout the record (Figure S1).
